cards.que: The use of a security policy to define management intention is an example of which access control type?
cards.a: A. Administrative
cards.b: B. Physical
cards.c: C. Technical
cards.d: D. Preventative
cards.ans: A. Administrative

cards.que: Which statement about guidelines is correct?
cards.a: A. They describe the steps required to complete and activity.
cards.b: B. They describe a required use of specific tools.
cards.c: C. They are recommended settings or actions.
cards.d: D. They specify the minimum security required for a system.
cards.ans: C. They are recommended settings or actions.

cards.que: The CIA triad is considered central to security. Which option best describes what it helps protect against?
cards.a: A. Disclosure, loss, and leakage
cards.b: B. Destruction, alteration, and disclosure
cards.c: C. Confidentiality, integrity, and availability
cards.d: D. Unavailability, downtime, and destruction
cards.ans: B. Destruction, alteration, and disclosure

cards.que: Which statement best describes security policies?
cards.a: A. They are operational instructions for implementing security.
cards.b: B. They document high level expectations from senior management.
cards.c: C. They detail tactical instructions for implementing security.
cards.d: D. They are work procedures specified by senior management.
cards.ans: B. They document high level expectations from senior management.

cards.que: The first step in risk analysis is to:
cards.a: A. Conduct a threat assessment.
cards.b: B. Identify assets and their value.
cards.c: C. Identify potential vulnerabilities.
cards.d: D. Identify the countermeasures.
cards.ans: B. Identify assets and their value.

cards.que: A business impact analysis (BIA) often includes which of the following security processes?
cards.a: A. A vulnerability assessment.
cards.b: B. Installing network countermeasures.
cards.c: C. Training of key personnel.
cards.d: D. A disaster recovery process
cards.ans: A. A vulnerability assessment.

cards.que: Which statement best describes the primary purpose of a business continuity plan?
cards.a: A. To ensure that the company will recover from one-time disasters.
cards.b: B. To ensure business processes may continue after a disruption or crisis.
cards.c: C. To identify key players in the business and enable succession planning.
cards.d: D. To keep key business documents available when and where they are needed.
cards.ans: B. To ensure business processes may continue after a disruption or crisis.

cards.que: Which of the following demonstrate the legal concept of due care? (Choose 2)
cards.a: A. Providing appropriate security training for all employees.
cards.b: B. Performing background checks on all prospective employees.
cards.c: C. Securing customers' personal information on the organization's servers.
cards.d: D. Performing risk assessments on network systems.
cards.ans: A. and C.

cards.que: Your company just recently acquired a smaller organization in the same industry. Which of the following is the most significant security risk as a result of this acquisition?
cards.a: A. The other organization may have a different C-level structure than yours.
cards.b: B. There may be a disparity between each organization's level of security.
cards.c: C. The other organization may use different access control mechanisms than yours.
cards.d: D. There may be a disparity between each organization's security budget.
cards.ans: B. There may be a disparity between each organization's level of security.

cards.que: Which of the following is a privacy law that protects users' financial information when it is held by banks and other financial institutions?
cards.a: A. Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
cards.b: B. Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA)
cards.c: C. Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA)
cards.d: D. Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)
cards.ans: D. Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)

cards.que: True or false? Patent protection is stronger and lasts longer than copyright protection.
cards.ans: False

cards.que: Which of the following is a comprehensive set of processes that can increase the effectiveness and decrease the complexity of security-focused operations?
cards.a: A. Governance, risk management, and compliance
cards.b: B. Governance, risk analysis, and risk mitigation
cards.c: C. Governance, risk management, and training
cards.d: D. Risk management, compliance, and training
cards.ans: A. Governance, risk management, and compliance

cards.que: Which of the following are goals of the (ISC)^2 Code of Ethics? (Choose 3)
cards.a: A. Behaving responsibly, justly, honestly, honorably, and legally.
cards.b: B. Improving, enhancing, and protecting the profession.
cards.c: C. Ensuring, enabling, and supporting the exchange of free information.
cards.d: D. Providing adept, competent, and assidious service to principals.
cards.ans: A., B., and D.

cards.que: Which of the following are key tasks in upholding organizational ethics? (Choose 3)
cards.a: A. Weighing ethical actions in relation to cost or benefit to the organization.
cards.b: B. Hiring and retaining employees that have a strong ethical background.
cards.c: C. Acting responsibly to the organization's stakeholders and to the public.
cards.d: D. Adhering to established standards and laws that outline ethical behavior.
cards.ans: B., C., and D.

cards.que: True or false? In a Platform as a service (PaaS) model, the responsibility for security is on the vendor.
cards.ans: False

cards.que: The company you acquired had its own set of security policies that governed its operations. What is the most important thing to consider regarding these policies?
cards.a: A. Make sure the acquired company's policies don't contradict your own.
cards.b: B. Make sure the acquired company's policies are written in your style.
cards.c: C. Make sure the acquired company's policies address all of your systems.
cards.d: D. Make sure your policies incorporate every item from the acquired company's policies.
cards.ans: A. Make sure the acquired company's policies don't contradict your own.

cards.que: Which of the following is a rating system that determines the impact of a threat?
cards.a: A. Damage, interruption, reproducibility, exploitability (DIRE)
cards.b: B. Harm, affected users, reproducibility, manageabilitiy (HARM)
cards.c: C. Tampering, harm, reproducibility, exploitability, affected users, thoroughness (THREAT)
cards.d: D. Damage, reproducibility, exploitability, affected users, discoverability (DREAD)
cards.ans: D. Damage, reproducibility, exploitability, affected users, discoverability (DREAD)

cards.que: The STRIDE acronym is a threat classification that includes which of the following?
cards.a: A. Spoofing, tampering, reflection, integrity violation, denial of service, escalation
cards.b: B. Spoofing, tampering, repudiation, information disclosure, denial of service, elevation of privilege
cards.c: C. Systems hacking, threatening, restructuring, information disclosure, destruction, elevation of privilege
cards.d: D. Systems hacking, tampering, repudiation, impersonation, destruction, elevation of privilege
cards.ans: B. Spoofing, tampering, repudiation, information disclosure, denial of service, elevation of privilege

cards.que: What is the typical flow of a threat tree diagram, from top (beginning) to bottom (end)?
cards.a: A. Identify the threat, identify how to mitigate the threat, identify who or what should implement the mitigation
cards.b: B. Identify the threat, identify how the threat can occur, identify how to mitigate the threat
cards.c: C. Identify how the threat can occur, identify what systems are vulnerable, identify how to mitigate the threat
cards.d: D. Idenitfy how the threat can occur, identify the source of the threat, idenitfy how to mitigate the threat
cards.ans: B. Identify the threat, identify how the threat can occur, identify how to mitigate the threat

cards.que: What is an employee's senstitivity profile?
cards.a: A. A description of the employee's technical level of access to sensitive systems.
cards.b: B. A description of the employee's trustworthiness with regard to keeping sensitive information secure.
cards.c: C. A description of the employee's need-to-know information based on their job role.
cards.d: D. A description of the employee's need-to-know information based on them as an individual.
cards.ans: C. A description of the employee's need-to-know information based on their job role.

cards.que: When providing security training to senior management and the board of directors, what should be the primary focus of this training?
cards.a: A. Basic computer security practices like using strong passwords and browsing the web safely.
cards.b: B. The details of security documents like policies, procedures, and guidelines.
cards.c: C. The importance of security in supporting business objectives, legal compliance, and shareholder expectations.
cards.d: D. The latest knowledge of the various threats and controls that affect information security.
cards.ans: C. The importance of security in supporting business objectives, legal compliance, and shareholder expectations.

cards.que: At minimum, how often should staff undergo security awareness training?
cards.a: A. Six months
cards.b: B. One year
cards.c: C. Two years
cards.d: D. Five years
cards.ans: B. One year

cards.que: As part of a security training program, which of the following is the most important for all staff to learn?
cards.a: A. Best practice for VPN usage.
cards.b: B. How to clean an infected computer.
cards.c: C. How to properly wipe sensitive data.
cards.d: D. How to identify social engineering attempts.
cards.ans: D. How to identify social engineering attempts.

cards.que: What are the 3 security goal categories, designed to address short, medium, and long term goals? (List in order from short to long)
cards.ans: Operational (specific short-term), tactical (months/a year), strategic (years)

cards.que: What is a control framework? Define and name 2 examples.
cards.ans: A control framework seeks to minimize the risk in an organization by creating a structure for the organization's security controls. They are a subset of overall security frameworks. 2 examples are NIST SP 800-53 and ISO 27001
Anything of value that could be compromised, stolen, or harmed, includuing information, systems, personnel, physical resources, and reputation.
Any event or action that could potentially cause damage to an asset or an interruption of services.
A person, group, or other entity that could potentially attack, damage, or otherwise compromise a system or resource.

A condition that leaves the system and its assets open to harm - including things such as software bugs, insecure passwords, inadequate physical security, poorly designed networks, or insufficient user training and awareness.
A technique that takes advantage of a vulnerability to perform an attack.
The likelihood of a threat occurring, as well as its potential damage to assets.
A countermeasure that you put in place to avoid, mitigate, or counteract security
The active attempt by a threat actor to break into
The result of a successful attack. Can include theft, destruction, or loss of availability of data, a system, or other resources.
The level, usually expressed in percentage, to which a resource is at direct risk of attack.
The practice of using deception and trickery against human beings as a method of attack.
The practice of providing security in multiple layers for more comprehensive protection against attack.

Behavioral expectations that organizations must adhere to. Ex: provide appropriate security training for all employees. 'Prudent person' or 'reasonable person' rule. Failing in due care is negligence, a legal offense.
Research necessary to make good, informed decisions. Ex: background checks on employees, testing of backup services.
Protects privacy of individual info held by US government. Applies to all personal information, provides for restrictions on individual access, and enforces penalties for authorized disclosure.

cards.que: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act)
cards.ans: Protects privacy of educational information held in federally funded higher-learning institutions.

Made it a crime to snoop into employee activities while using electronic communications devices without notifying employees in advance of monitoring. Enforced requirement for legal authorization of wiretaps, other gov monitoring.

cards.que: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
cards.ans: Originally intended to protect people with health insurance when they transferred from one company to another. The privacy component adopted in 2003 protects a class of information called Protected Health Information (PHI).
Controls how corporations self-report and audit. Requires retention of long-term email, voicemail, and instant messaging records in corporations.
Personal Health Information. Any information that can identify a particular patient and includes a patient's medical record or payment history.
Protects privacy of an individual's financial information as held by financial and other isntitutions. Includes privacy standard and rules to safeguard info; provides penalties for violations.

Protects online privacy of children. Restrictions inlcude rights to: opt out of info sent by a provider; limit amount and type of info collected from children; require parental consent for info provided to children.

cards.que: USA PATRIOT Act (Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism)

cards.ans: Provides consumers with ability to view, correct, contest, and limit use of their information in a credit report.
Requires federal agencies to develop, document, and implement an agency-wide information security program.
Used to access and analyze law enforcement and intelligence information from government agencies to fight terrorism.

cards.que: ESIGN (Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act)
cards.ans: Facilitates use of electronic signatures and electronic records in both domestic (interstate) and foreign commerce.
Criminalizes dissemination of technologies or actual attempts to circumvent digital rights management of copyrighted works.
Makes theft of trade secrets and economic espionage a federal crime.

cards.que: What is the name of the framework that helps organizations comply with foreign laws and regulations?
cards.ans: US-EU Safe Harbor Protection Framework

cards.que: EU GDPR applies to all organizations that offer goods or services to EU customers. What does it extend the concept of personal data to include?
cards.ans: Photos/audio/video, social media posts, location data, financial transactions, device identifiers, login credentials, browsing history

Protects government systems from illegal access or from exceeding access permissions. Prohibited activities include: retrieving information without authorization, trafficking passwords, sending viruses or worms to infect computers, etc.
Key requirements: fulfill training needs and plan development for information and systems security. (Replaced by FISMA)
Created legal remedies for hacking, stealing trade secrets, and damaging systems and information. Targeted internet infrastructure security in particular.

Passed to remedy evolutionary nature of info systems security in federal government. Some key provisions include: define boundaries of system to be protected and identify types of info within that system; continuously monitor systems for proper operations; document and perform system risk assessments.

Protects item's creator from competition for a given time period. Very strong, but patent owners have responsibility to protect their patents. Strongest form of protection for IP. In the US, lasts for 20 years.
A design or phrase used to identify unique products or services. In the US, lasts 10 years and can be renewed.
Protects and original artistic work. Not as strong as patent protection, but the length of protection is much greater. Weakest from of IP protection.
